div.head: THE MOHAMEDANS OF INDIA.
div.p: In the strange and romantic history of British rule in India, no incident of a pacific character has been more remarkable than the presentation last week to the Vicerory of the Mohamedan memorial. Its significane, says the "Daily Telegraph," is two-fold. In the first place, the sincere and unambiguous declaration of loyalty to the Raj, sponstaneously made in the name of the Mohamedans of India, comes opportunely at a moment when there is a determined effort in the Nearer EAst to foment a Pah-Islamic agitation. It is by no means certain that this movement was originated by Mualems. It is very well known konw that one of the causes of the Sultan's obduarcy with regard to the Turco-Eguptian boundary was the urgency with which some of his representatives in the Khediavale assured him that any weakening on his part would be followed bu a succession from the faith to the part of Egyptian Mohamedans. In the second place, the organization and character of the deputation which waited upon Lord Minto constituted a counterbalst to the aims and methods of certain Hindu politicans under the leadership of Mr. Surendra Nath Banergee. These Badu incendiaries have not restricted themselves to constitutional forms of agitation, though their machinery and their ideals are borrowed wholesale from the West. Banda and banners and processions do not appeal to the "brooding East" ; but any suggestion of religious or radical oppression is eagerly listened to and easily exaggerated. Englishmen and Anglo-Indians - all but a few - took years to realise that there was a genuine grievance in the story of the "greased cartridges," which was the occasion, though not the cause, of the Mutiny. The West, in its haste and hurry, soon forgets; the East remembers. The Bengali agitators have not forgotten the greased cartridges and their sequel. The breechloader has rendered that cry obsolete, but today the political heirs of the mjtineers are telling Mohomedans that sugar they consume is refined with pigs blood, and the Hindus are informed that the blood of cows is used the same purpose. With these sedition-mongers the Mohamedan population will have nothing to do. The deputation which waited upon Lord Minto "gratefully acknowledged the peace, security, and liberty of the person and of worship conferred by the British Government, emphasising the fact one of the most imporatnt charactersitics of British rule was the deference paid to the veiws and wishes of all the races and religions of India."

It may resonably be asked: Why, if the Mohamedans are satisfied with their condition , should they think it worth while to memorialise the Viceroy at all. The answer is not far to seek. Though India had a civilisation, a polity, and a literature many centuries before England, in none of the innumberable chances and changs which have overtaken her heterogeneous inhabitants has the seef of self-government ever taken root. Indeed, it never was sown. Self-government, as we understand the word, is purely Teutonic in origin, and has only developed naturally amongst people of Teutonic blood. And pride of race has led Anglo-Saxons to believe that the form of constitution that best adapated their genius and traditions must be beat adapted to the needs of all races under the sun. Radicials became almost Turcophil when, for a month or two, a Parliament was in existence in Constantinople, and Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman only echoed the race arrogance when he declared, "The Duma is dead; long live the Duma!" If the Hindu movement in favour of self-government for India were spontaneous and indigenous, it would be worthy of all consideration. But it is an extoic, imported from allen climes. The political slang, the catchwords, the emblems, the ideas emploued by the agitators might have been turned out of the literary factory of the National Liberal Federation. There is a very small percentage of Anglo-Indian retired Civil Servants who support and encourage the "mild Hindu." Of course there is. The system by which we selecet our Indian Civil Service - though undoubtedly the best available - is certain to produce a minority of clever cranks, who, though capable of passing every kind of "examination," are most ignorant of human nature than their native servants. A few of them, reutrn home with pensions at a comparetively early age, get themselves elected for Parliament, and talk plausible nonsense to ignorant people in the House of Commons and on public platforms. And gradually these persons, doctrinaire Radicals of the most unpratical kind, impress upon their countrymen the idea that India is clamouring for self-goverment. India is not clamouring. But self-government in some form may be thrust upon her, and the Mohamedans who waited on Lord Minto only asked that if the "blessing" is granted, they and their co-religionists should be duly represented. Lord Minto's reply - discussed, no doubt, in anticipation with Mr. John Morley - was admirable. "Hope and ambitions," he said, "new to India are making themselves felt. We cannot ignore them. I should be wrong were I to wish you to do so but what is all this unrest due. Not to the discontent of misgoverned milllions. I defy anyone honestly to assert that. Nor is it due to any uprising of disaffected people. It is due to that educational growth in which only a very small portion of the population has yet shared, of which British rule first sowed the seed, and the fruit of which British rule is now doing its best to foster and direct. There may be many tares in the harvest we are now reaping. The Western grain which we have sown may not be entirely suitable to the requirementes of the people of India." This is sound commonsense, and must comforted the Mohamedans, but we fear that to the Surrendra Nath Banerjees it will prove a stumbling-block, and to the Cottons and KeirHardies foolishness, or at least irony.

div.head: Ras-el-Bar.
div.p: The telegraph office at Ras-el-Bar will be closed for the season today.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's plaue bulletin records a fatal case and recovery at Alexandria.

div.head: Tram Accident.
div.p: A Student of Al Azbar University had both legs margled on Monday beneath the wheels of a tram near Shourbra.

div.head: Pensions.
div.p: The staffs of the various Government departments have petitioned Sir Vincent Corbett to increase their pensions.

div.head: The Brindisl Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distrivuted at the G.P.O Alexandria at 9 p.m. today.

div.head: Menshawl Pasha's Estate.
div.p: The sum of L.E. 450 has been distributed to the legatees of the estate left by Menshawi Pasha for beneficentt purposes.

div.head: Royal Berks.
div.p: The detachment of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berk Regiment in Cairo will move from the Citadel into camp at Abbassieh on the 15th inst.

div.head: New Station.
div.p: On Thursday next, the State Railway Administration will inaugurate a new station between Shagab and Matarieh. The new station will be called "Al-Moulls."

div.head: Military School.
div.p: Fifteen candidates have been admitted to the Military School in Cairo and as there is room for fiften more the date on which admission terminates is extended to January 1, 1907.

div.head: Helouan Roads.
div.p: The State grant of L.E. 3,200 is being wholly devoted to the repair of the roads of Helouan. Thus far the Rue des Hotels and the Rue de la Gare have been completely repaired.

div.head: White Cross League.
div.p: The White Cross League met on Monday night at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute, Alexandria, under the presidency of the REv. Canon Ward, when a debate took place on "Monarchy v. Republicanism."

div.head: Beni Souef.
div.p: A subscription has been opened in Beni Souef for a professional school and has thus far realised L.E. 2,920. Fifty-five feddans of and have been offered, the rental from which will go towards an endowment fund.

div.head: Survey Department.
div.p: Owing to the Agricultural Society holding a show at Tantah tomorrow, the Observatory at Helonan will be specially opened to visitors on the following Thursday instead, on the 18th inst., instead of the 11th as previously notified.

div.head: Record Passenger List.
div.p: The S.S. Hobenzollern, of the Nordeentober Lloyd, which arrived at Alexandria on Monday landded nearly 350 passengers this being the greatest number ever brought either to Alexandria or Port said by a passenger steamer of a regular line.

div.head: Alharambra Theatre.
div.p: The Zane Fantoches will give their last two performances at the Alhambra this afternoon and evening. Tomorrow night, the well-known Italian actor Signor Giovanni Novelli's company will commence return visist with Sardon's famous Odette, which should draw a good house.

div.head: Murderer Arrested.
div.p: The murderer of M. Bolas, the nazir of M. Philippo Philippides, has been arrested. The crime was, as yeasterday reported, committed on the esbeh of M.Philippides, near the Delta Barrage, and M. Bolas received a fatal charge of buckshot in the back. Benegeance was the motive of the crime.

div.head: Erratum.
div.p: In our issue of Monday we erroneously reported the decoration by the Khedive of Mr. Bliss, chief engineer of the Mahroussa, witht the 3rd Class of the Order of the Osmneih. The chief engineer of the Khedivial yacht is Mr. Andrew Taylor, and the decoration was conferred upon Mr. Biles, Professor of Naval Architecture at G'asgow Univerisity, who made the journey to Alexandria vias Constatinople.

div.head: A Canal Mystery.
div.p: The inquest on the body of the Coptic girl which was recently found in the Mumoudieh Canal, has been productive of no definite result as yet. The Alexandria authorities have received a communication from Minieh to the effect that a Coptic girl has recently disappeared from the moudirieh, but whether that girl is the one whose body was found has not been determined, although there is a strong probability that she is.

div.head:
FAMOUS ACTRESS DEAD.
SIGNORA ADELAIDE RISTORI.
div.p: The celebrated tragedienne, Signora Adelaide Ristori, is dead. (Reuter)

The Marquise del Grillo, nee Adelaide Ristori, trafic actress, was born at Cividale, in Friuli, in 1821, being the child of a poor actor, and was trained at a very early age for the stage. She appears to have risen through a long series of struggles to the eminence she ultimately attained. Having accepted in 1855 an engagement in Paris, she sought the favour of a French audience as a interpreter of the tragic muse at the very time that Rochel was in the zenith of her fame. Her appearance at such a period was regarded by the French as an open challenege to contest the supremacy of their tragic queen, and they assembled much more dispoed to criticise than to applaud. The genius of Ristori, however, trimphed, and from that moment her position was unassailed. Her reception in England was equally enthusiatic, and she appeared in Spain in 1857, in Hollan in 1860, in Russia in 1861, at Constainople I 1864, in the United States and other parts of the world, with success. William I. of Prussia gave her the medal in sciences and in arts in 1862. Amongst her most famous characters are those of Medes, Lady Macbeth, Fazio, Phaedra, Deborah, Judith, Franceca da Riviera, and Camilla. After an absence of fifteen yars, Madame Ristori again appeared in London, June 11, 1878, and on Nov. 8 in that year she took her farewell of the English stage at Queen's Theatre, manchester. She appeared again, however, on a few occasions in the year 1882, and acted Lady Macbeth with all her old distinction if with some lack of fire. In 1887 she published "Estudes et Souvenire." She was married to the Marquis Capranica del Grillo.

div.head: AMERICAN SQUADRON AT PORT SAID.
div.p: The Fourth Division of the American Atlantic fleet, consisting of the four armoured cruisers, West Virgina, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Colorado, under the commnad of Vice-Admiral Brownson, arrived at Port Said this morning shorly after ten o'clock and will make a stay of five days revious to proceeding to the Philippine Islands.

All four vessels are of the same type and were laid down in 1901. Sheathed they have a displacement of 13,800 tons, and unsheathed 13,400 tons and a maximum speed of 22 knots, with a horse power of 23,000.

The Division had been detached from the Atlantic fleet, and is now en route to the Aisatic station Until reaching Suez the fleet will be known as the Special Service squadron. Upon passing the Suez Canal the vessels will be considered as attached to the Asiatic fleet, and Admiral Brownson will assume the title of Commander-in-Chief of the Asiatic Fleet.

div.head: AMERICAN EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: A special commerical agent has made a report to the United States Burean of manufactures upon the possibilities of enlarging the volume of experts to Egypt. At present these are not aufficiently important to trecieve particular classification in the Egyptian returns. For the fiscal year 1906 the United States took from Egypt goods to the value of $9,391,621, to which Egyptian cotton was by far the largest contributor, but the balye of the exports to Egypt was only $1,163,128. Our American friends seem almost unduly anxious to extend their export tade, and it is suggested that the backwardness in this cases in due mainly to inadequate steamship connection are blamed for the loss of business in locomotives and in bridge-bulding. It is said that there is an opportunity for American enterprise in the demand for agricultural machinery, electrical applicanes, and motor-cars. On the whole the summary of the report gives the impression that the desired end has not been brought much nearer.

div.head: SUDAN AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: One of the main points of the convention with regard to Abyssinia, signed in July last by Great Britain, France,, and Italy, was that England shoulb be enabled to carry on the line from Adis Abeba to the Nile. This convention has not yet been accepted by the Emperor Menelik, as the convention, it is believed, has caused some dissatifaction amoung certain groups of financiers at Menelik's Court, who habe succeeded in convincing him that the Powers concerned must have had a peculiar idea of his independence when they took the liberty of settling Abyssinian affairs without his consent. These financiers habe advised him to resist, and he accordingly refuses to ratify the convention.

div.head: LOCUSTS AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: Lousts have appeared in the northern part of Khartoum province, and 400 Egyptian troops have been sent to destroy them. The "Sudan Times" says that unless they are promptly destroyed the pests will do much harm.
Lucusts are also reported at Jassala on land which could not be irrigated owing to the breakdown of the irrigation works by the recent flood.

div.head:
THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
HOW HISTORY IS WRITTEN.
div.p: A correspondent writes:- The following passage from a leading article in a recent issue of the "Daily Telegraph," reporduced in the "Egyptian Gazette" of the 6th inst., deserves special notice at the present moment:-

"The outcry against the punishment of the Egyptian villagers who act upon and murdered some British officers has hardly yet died away. Lord Cromer's measured warning to the Home Government of the growth of a fanatic anti-British agitation in Egypt is either derided, byt these 'anti-nationalist,' or it is accepted as natural and worthy of all sympathy."

Is not the use of the word "Some" in this connection an exaggeration so gross as to amount to a perversion of the truth. the "outcry" has not died away, nor will it be allowed to do so as long as hournalists and others in a more respoinsble positions are constatnly allyding to it whilst distorting the clearly proved facts. It is easy to carp at the natove Moslem newspapers for their mistatementa of facts in roder to prove their points, but it is at the same time the duty of fairminded Englishmen to show that it is not only the vernacular Press which is guilty of perverting the truth as to the Denishwai affair, and that an imporatnt London Imperialist oragan, such as is the"Daily Telegraph," can be proved to be quite as prone to texaggerate most grossly in the other direction. Many readers of the aritlce in question will, froma persual of the allegatio to which I have drawn attention, come to a hazy conclusion that there was regular massacre of British officers. The public memory is proverbially ahort, and after a few months the details of the denishwai business are to most people in England of the flimisiest kind. Most, no doubt, after all the talk that has subsequently ensured about Egyptian unrest and Pan-Islamism, consider it as a deliberately planned outrage instigated by the emissaries od the Sultan and, aided by such untruths as that in the "Daily Telgraph," they naturally conclude that Egypt is in a state of furious turmoil. The "Egyptian Gazette" is, in my opinion, a very impartial organ, and I have therefore addressed these remarks to you, Sir, as I think some protest should be made against such gross exaggeration.

We willingly print the letter of our correspondent as the statement in our London contemporaty deserves to be notes. The exaggeration of the London Conservative newspaper that "some" British officers were murdereded is on a par with the perservsions in Mr. Blunt's pamphlet or in the vernacular novel, "the Virgin of Denishwai." They show that that the Denishwai Affair is gadually entering on a mythoric process and soon all attempts to obtain any unbaiseed opinion on the matter will be beyond the scope of the human intellect, for it appears to be one of those incidents, like the Drefus Affair, which seem destined to be distorted by every person who attempts to arrive at a conclusion on the subject.

div.head: REFORM OF CADRES.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has requested the Ministries and Administrations of State to inform it of the number of the employes who receive gratifications and the reasons therefore; also that of employes who occupy Government houses and the rent they pay.

div.head: FAYOUM FOSSILS.
div.p: A German correspondent writes to correct the improession that Germany has neglected geological research in regard to the Fayoum fossil remains. The museum of Stuttgart contains an excellent collection of Fayoum fossils. Last year Professor Frass, the director of the Stuttgrat Museum, came to the Egypt and was for some time in the Fayoum collecting speciemens. He has published an account of his trip in "Kosmos," a Struttgart scientific review, under the title of Wustenreise Eines Geologen in "Egyptian."

div.head: EGYPTOLOGY IN MANCHESTER.
div.p: An association having for its object the promotion of the stufy of Egyptology was formed in Mancester last week. The inagural meetin gwas held in the Manchester Univeristy and the lines on which the society can work most profitably were laid down in an address by Professor Flinders Petrie. It has been through that there are many persons in the city and neighbourhood who would be glad of opportunities of meeting regularly to have news of recent progress in the exploration of Egypt and to discuss questions of interst as to the lanuge, literature, and archeology of the country. The Manchester Museum possesses a valuable collection of speciemens-described at the meeting as the finest in respect of small objects after Oxford,-and these will greatly aid the society in its studies. There is a large and increasing collection of works on the subkect in the University libray. A class for the stufy of hieroglyphics has been carried on at the Univeristy for some time with much success, and about fity people have passed through it. It is thorugh that these students together with the manu persons who are interested in the progress of Egyptian research will help to form the nuclues of the new society.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head:
NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
SUBSCRIPTIONS COMING IN.
div.p: Hussein Bey El-Bskri, of Damietts, has contributed L.E. 1,000 for the proposed National University, Mohamed Pasha Muhein L.E. 200, and Sauid Mahmoud El Soursi L.E. 500.
Sayid Mohamed, a merchant of Gamaleih, who was reported by the "Lewa" to have subscribed L.E. 1,500. writes to that paper to contradict the statement.

The news of the enormous donation of L.E. 100,000 from Aly Pasha Fahmy, which was recently published by "Al-Minbar." proves to be unfounded. Interviewed in regard to the matter, his Excellency merely stated that he would contribute a sum towards the scheme when the committee had been composed and the president elected.
The total subscriptions received or promised amount to L.E. 26,450.

Mohamed Bey Fraid, who orginated the scheme of giving a barquet in honour of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, writes to "Al Lewa" saying that the money collected for the purpose of the reception has now been placed in the Bank of Salonics, ready to be paid over to the committee of the National University as ssoon as it has commenced its labours.
The meeting of the subscribes, for the election of an organising committee, will be held at the residence of Saad Bey Zaghloul, councillor in the Natiove Court of Appeal, at Iosha, on Friday next.

It is stated that number of Syrian notables, resident in Cairo, met yesterday evening in order to consider the scheme of the proposed National University. Some of them intend to subscribe a considerable amount towards the scheme.

div.head: CONSECRATION OF NEW MASONIC LODGE.
div.p: It will be interesting to our Masonic readers to known that on Monday last new lodge, named the United Service Lodge of Alexandria, working in the English language, was consecreated with due solemnity at the Old Masonic Hall, Alexandria, under a charter from the National Grand Lodge of Egypt.

This lodge is intended to supply a long felt want among the breathren of the Army of Occupation, Police, Coastguard, and civillians who are in the Government Service, and who have little change of obtaining office in the lodges already established in our city.

The ceremony was very ably conducted by W. Bro Button, P.G.S, and all those who had the good fortune to be present were much impressed by the solemnity of the proceedings. The installation of the W. Master and officers was next proceeded with, W. Bro Lumsden, P.G.S., being the installing Master; and it has seldom been our good fortune to see the ceremony conducted with such fluency and solemnity as on this occasion. The following are the officers who were duly installed for the susing twelve months: - W. Bros. F. G. Bright, W.M.; Allen Borman (acting) I.P.M; H.B. Wall, S.W.; A.R. Williams, J.W.; E.A. Colvin, treasurer; E.J. Tilbury, secretary; A. H. Gardust, S.D.; W. Saunders, J.D.; J. Hosford, I.G.; J. Duncan, D. of C.

We offer our sincere congratulations to W. Bro. Lumsden on the most imporessive manner in which the ceremonies were carried out, and also to the breathren who have been elected to the offices for the first time, and turst they may have success and bring the United Service Lodge of Alexandria to be one of the brightest lights of Masonary, for the predection of its working.
We are informed that this lodge was promoted by the Ragheb Lodge of Cairo, and has no less than 46 founders.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: Messer, Collinge Brothers have received the following New York cable: - United States Weekly Burean. Weather genearlly unfavourable over cotton belt. Frost reported northern territories Texas.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Florio-Rubattino S.S. Enna left Naples yesterday morning on an extraordinary voyages, and is due at Alexandria on Saturday morning.
The Ellerman S.S. Avon sailed from Malta last night and is due here on Saturday morning with general cargo.
The S.S. Syrian Prices with passengers and general cargo left Malta on 9th inst., and is due at Alexandria Saturday morning.
The S.S. Sailor Prince with passengers and general cargo left matla on 9th inst. and is due at Alexandria Saturday morning.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsbiel for the opinions expressed by our coresspondents in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER CO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - There was a notable omissin in your report of the fire at Sochutz last (Monday) night. When the Alexandria Fire Brigade appeared on the scene there was not a drop of water available. The police did all they possibly could. They telephoned for water to the Alexandria Water Company and sent mounted policemen post haste to the company's station at Hagar Nawatieh. All their efforts, however, were fruitless.

Not a drop of water was obtainable. The result was that the house was completely gutted and, had there been a wind, the houses in the immediate neighbourhood would habe fallen a prey to the flames. How long will the inhabitatnts of Ramleh remain callous of the terrible danger which menaces them owing to the extraordinary conduct of the Alexandria Water Company - Truly yours,

div.head: THE STREETS OF CAIRO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - The streets of Cairo are in such a condition, owing to road-mending, house building, and similary operations, that it is becoimng almost impossible to either walk or drive with safety. Buildings must be erected and road must be mended, but Cairenes have the right to demand that some atttention should be paid to their daftey and comfort. In many quarters the Government are infringing their own regulations by recumbering the pavements with repairing materials and, such being the case, they cannot but countenance the unnecessary blocking of the pathways by building contractors.

In a recent leading article you remakred upon the sad lack of traffic control in Ciairo. We have hoped for better things by the drafiting of men from the Police School, but matters certainly have not been improved by these "boys" - for such they appear both in age and intellect.

I should also like to remark upon the ruin of our once beautiful suburb. Ghizeh. Its glory has gone for ever and Cairo is being robbed of one more life supporting lung. all is bein gbuilt over - the Wakf land, the land between the river and the road, those beautiful gardens south of the old Museum, which stretched to the Ghizeh Reformatory. Those lovely gardens, once the pride of Cairo, have vanished beyond recall. Oh that these destroyers would stay their hands and remember that "God the first garden made, and the first city Cain." - Yours, etc., CAIRENE.

div.head: THE ISIS MISHAP.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - In reference of the various theories of your correspondents as to the orgiin of the mishap to the P. & O. steamer Isis, I should like to point out that it is improbable that the machinery of the streamer was imperfect, or out of order, as she no doubt has a passengers' certificate from the Board of Trade, delcaring from one date to another that she is in a fit and proper condition to convey mails, passengers, and cargo. - Truly yours, MARINER.

div.head: TRANSLITERATION OF PLACE NAMES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir, - I recently spent a few days in a town on the banks of the Nile situate between the stations of Armant and Kous. Throughout my sojourn I was never quite clear in my mind as to whether I was really staying at Luxor, for on reference to my map of the district the only name which I could find in the precise region where I imagined myself to be was splet El Uksor. A few days later received a letter from the place where I thought I had been, but the postmark was Louqsor. Subsequently I had occasion to visit a village between the station of Michta (or Mecheta) and Sidfs (or Sedfa). It was evening, and I had lasped into a transiet slumber in the corner of my carriage. "To sleep; perchance to dream: ay, there's the rub," and my dreams had carried me back to my student days. I was aroused by the train slowing up and on entering the station I received a "coup d'ceil" in the shape of the legend "Time" brought into strong relief against the blackness of the night by a (1) candlepower lamp. Was this a continuity of my dream in which I had heard that very word echoing through the halls of gaily lighted tavern. I hurriedly consulted my watch and time table and, placing strict reliance in both, I should have arrived at Tema. Where I had just been reading an Eue's Fruit Salt advertisment in illustrated paper heaed "Time" with a pictured presentement o fth ehoary headed avenger armed with a seythe. It was all very bewildering and - where was I.

Did Shakespeare live at Guerga in the present day he might vary the spelling of his dwelling place as frewuently as the spelling of his name, claiming the authority of the Railway, Postal, or Survey Administration for most of his departures. Probably, though, he would adhere to one method; at least we have no reason to thick the contraty. Shall I multiply instance. Remembering the Eno's Fruit Salt advertisment and the stentorian voice of my dreams, I stay my pen. Was President Roosevelt travelling incognito in Egypt during last winter. - Yours faithfully, G.H. LUDOLF.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H Prince Kamal ed-Din Pasha returned to Cairo from Alexandria yesterday.

Lord Cromer arrived at Balmoral Castle yesterday week the Right Hon. Sir Charles hardings, Permanent Under Secreatry of State for Foreign Affairs. His lordship was received in private audience by the King on the following day.
The Sirdar will probably remain in CAiro until November in order to study the Sudan Budget of 1907 in conjunction with the Egyptian Government.
The Hon. L. Morris Iddings, American Diplamtic Agent and Consul General at Cairo, is expected to arrive at Alexandria from Europe on the 22nd inst. by the north German Lloyd steamer.
Miralai Sir H.B. Hill, Bar., has been appointed Governor of the Bahr el Ghazal.
Coles Pasha, Inspector General of Prisions, is expected to return from England on the 27th inst.
Mr. Percy Chataway, Adiminstrator of the Alexandria Municiplaity, arrived at Port Said today by the Brindisi mail steamer, and is due at Alexnadria this evening.

Major Joly de la Lothbiniere, R.E., who has been engaged in district work at Lichfield, is coming out immediately to Egypt, and has been appointed to the Egyptian Army. He will subseqeuently be posted to a high position in the Survery Department, as already announced.
Major H.M. Finch, Royal Berkshire Regimeut, reutring from Egypt, has been appointed for duty at the Reading depot, in succession to Major W. Clegg, retired.

The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Captain John George Albert Massy, Royal Irish Regiment, his Majesty's Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insiguia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, conferred upon him by his Highness th eKhedive, authorisied by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of his services in the Egyptian Army.
Mustapha Bey Wassef, judge in the Keneh Native Court, will be allowed to tretire on pension at the end of this year.
Sabir Bey Sabri, chief architect to the Wak, will shortly retire on pension, for reasons of health.
H.I.M. the Sultan has conferred the third class of the medjidieh on Dr. Sadek Bey Ramadan, of the Maieh Sanieh, and Mahomoud Bey Mohamed, of the Khedive's Arabic Burean.
We regret to record the death of the baby daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Page-May, of Helouan, which occurred yesterday week at Knightsbridge.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
div.p: ARRIVALS,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui a midi et demie.)
L'attention a ete toute absorbes comatin par les Nungovich Hotels, les Delta Land, les Estates, le Comptoir et les Hooker.
De 17 ½ les Nungovich s'avancent a 17 11/16-3/4.
Les Delta Land gagnent 5/32 a 3 17/32
Sur le bruit d'une prochaine liquidation, les Hooker s'avancent a 1 1/32 pour finir vendeurs a 1 3/32.
Les actions Estates sont demandees a l 29/32. Quant aux parte de fondaetuer elles attaigunet £ 13.
En bausse de 1/16 le Cmptoir ancienne emission a'inscrit a 6 29/32 et la nonvelle a 6 21/32. La part de fundateur demenure stationnaire a 44.
Les autres valuers n'ont pas en d'animation. A penine si l'on constate quelques fluctuations insignifiantes.
Les Jouissances Eauz du Caire gagnent 2 a 266, la Diara 1/16 a 16 ¾, la Cassa di Soonoto 25 centimes a 228 et 222 ½, l'Ordinary Kehdivial Mail 4 peace et demi a 35.
Par contre, l'obligation Credit Foncier est plus faible a 337, l 'Anglo-American Nile a 3 11/32, la Banque d'Athenes a 143 ½ et l'Union Fonciere a 5 15/16.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le tax de l'esccompte librre a londres reste a 4 3/8 pour cent.

Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a culture invarie a 86 ½, de meme que l'Unifree a 104 ¼. La National Bank et l'Agricole, anisi que les autres valeurs egyptiennes, sont demeurees egalement inchange a leurs prix precedents.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier egyptien est restee immoblie a 779. La Banque d'Athenes a retrograde de 1 franc a 144. L'empruntruess 1906 a pase de 82,50 a 83,50.

Iei, le marche des valeurs a cesse de se laisser influencer par lagrande penurie d'or determinee par les transcations exceptionnelle du debut de la saison contoniere. Le terme de cette disette est, d'ailleurs, fixe a mardi prochain grace aux measures deja prises et aux arrivages de matal jaune attendus d'iei lendi. Aussi bien, la séance de ce matin a ete bonne; elle a servi a consolider et meme a secentuer l'avance acquise hier, en attendant la plus forte reprise qui semble s'annoncer a breve echeance, tout au moins pour plusiuer devises de la cote.

La National Bank a gagne 1/8 a 26 13/16. L;Agricole s'est raffermie a 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconbo a progresso a 228-229. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit a 6 13/16 l'action arcienne et 6 9/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Abyssinie s'est encore alourdie a 5 7/16-1/2.
Le Credit Froncier a ete mieuz tenu a 776. La Behera a progresse a 36 5/8.
L'action entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux a beneficle de 1/16 a 4 5/16 3/8; la part de fondateur a cloture demandee a 34.

La Delta Light a passe de 11 5/8 a 11 ¾. L'action de captial Eaux du Caire s'est consolidee a 124; les Jousisances ont atteint 266. la Frigorifique a rattrape le cours de 4 15/16. L'Anglo-American Nile a fait 5 3/8. Les parts de fondateur Automoblies du Caire ont ete traitees a 10 7/8.

Dans le groupe dos valeurs hotelieres, les Nungovich ont cloture rechercues a 17 ½ - 9/16. Les Egyptian sont remontes a 6 5/16 3/8. Les Upper Egypt ont debute a 5 pour atteindre 5 1/8, acheteurs, trevenir a 5 et terminer a 5 1/16-1/8. Les National ont retrograde a 3 15/16; la part de fondatuer a ete negociee a 59-60.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land, sur les quels on parait s'attendre a un proche mouvement ont ete bein tenns a 3 7/16. Les Hooker ont avance a 1 1/16, les Markets a 26 sh. 6, les New Egyptian a 30 sh, les Cotton Mills a 6 sh. et les Walker and Meimarachi a 11/16. Eu bonne tendances, les Estates ont progresse a 1 7/8 et leur part de fondatuey a 12 1/8. La Khedivial Mail a cloture ferme aux abords de 35 sh.
Il se confirme que le conesil d'administration de l'Egyptian Markets Co. a decide la distribution d'un dividende de 3% pour le premier semestre de l'exercice en cours.
Les journax locaus donnent quelques details sur l'arrangement intervenu recemment a Londres entre le Board de la Walker and Melmarachi Ltd. et M. Constaintin Meimarachi.

A'en croire cette version, M. Const. Meimarachi qui menacait de donner es demission, aurait finalement accepte de ne plus etre seul adminstrateur delegue de la Societe en Egypte; il aurs pour collegues MM. Geroge Walker et Hochatrasser.
Ou announce d'Alexandria le retour d'Eurore du baron de Jusel bey, directeur general de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Gly menopoulo)
Le harox revient pour cooperer a la liquidatio du Trust, lequel a ete, comme on sait, absorbe par la Building Landis Co.
Aux termes de l'arrangement intervann. l'exchange des titres sera fait a raision de 10 actions Glymeopule contre 2 action. Building Lands.
Hier a la bourse d'Alexandria, callese ci etatient cotes 4 13/16 et les actions du Trust 1 3/8-13/32.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Kafr-Zauat Cotton Co. sont conveques en assemble genearle ordinarie pour le 31 Octobre courant. A l'ordre du jour approbation des comptes de l'execrise arrete au 31 Juillet 1906; fixation du dividecide; nomination statutaires, etc.

Un avis official rappelle aux proteurs d'actions de la Menezaleh Canal and Naviagtion Cp. qu'aux termes de l'article 7 des Statuts tout tire qui ne porte pas la mention reguliere des versements appeles cease d'etre negociable. Touts somans non psyes le jour de son exigibilite porte de plein detroit en faveur de la Societe, un interet de 7% l'an a compter du dit jour.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST and INVESTMENT Ltd. (en liquidation)
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that those shareholders in the above Company who have not yet paid all their calls on shares held by them myst pay same on or before the 30th October 1906 to the Company's Baukers, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, Alexandria.

Having regard to the amalagamariem of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. with the Building Lands of Egypt its is necessary that all calls should be paid by the date above indicated, and further, shareholders owing calls will be unable to obtain their new shares in exchange for their present ones until they have paid their shares up in full. In the meantime, until payment of the calls, interest is according against shareholders until payment in made, at the rate of 10% per unrium.
Alexandria, 9 October, 1906.
By order,
Geo. T Broadbridue,
Liquidator.

div.head:
"DEATH TO THE JEWS."
A SCARE IN ODESSA.

div.p: The President of the "Union of Russian People" harangued a gang of 300 members exhorting them to exterminate the rebels and the Jews. Russia, he said, wanted neither Consitution nor Parliament but Orthodoxy and Autocracy. The gang rushed into the streets shouting "Death to the Jews." All the shops were instantly closed. The Jews became panic-stricken. The Perfect intervened and averted a massacre. (Reuter)

The reactionary party here held a meeting to consider the question of an anit-British demonstration in the event of the BRitish deputation visiting the city. The Liberal committee, on the other hand, are busy arranging a welcome. (Reuter)
Over 100 executions have taken place in Russia since the 3rd inst. (Reuter)
A newspaper states that tho Jews have been expelled from Vladivostock. (Havas)

The "Daily Mail" learns that a German syndicate has bough out the bulk of the English sharholders in the Whitworth collierises (Whales) and has asked the English directors to resign. It is understood that £250,000 has been paid for the estate, which is estimated to contain 375,000,000 tons of smokeless coal. (Reuter)

div.head:
GERMAN COAL AGITATION.
SERIOUS STRIKES THREATENED.

div.p: A serious agitation is taking place in German coal centres. Strikes for higher wages are being organized threatening dilocatin to industries throughout the ocuntry. An appeal to the English miners for support is contemplated. (Reuter)

div.head:
MINERS' THREATENED STRIKE.
WILL PROBABLY BE AVERTED.

div.p: The strike of the POnty Pridd and Rhondda Valley miners will probably be averted; the non-Unionists are numerously joining the Federation.
Mr. Smillie, the President of the Scottish Miners; Federation, speaking at Cardiff, said that Mr. Keir Hardie;s party welcomed the Liberal party's declaration of war. (Reuter)

div.head:
FURTHER IRISH DISLOYALTY.
CORPORATION APPROVES INSULT TO FLAG.

div.p: The Corporation yesterday refused to consider the resolution censuring the outrage on the Union Jack. The meeting separeted singing "God Save Ireland." (Reuter)

div.head:
THE PANAM CANAL.
COMPLETION BY CONTRACT.

div.p: It has been finally decided that the Panama Canal will be completed by contract. This decision will not affect the employment of Chinese labour. (Reuter)
Twenty-nine casualties amongst German troops occurred in the fighting in Damaraland from the 24th September to 4th October. (Reuter)
The Foreign Minister is about to visit Rome in order to endeavour to adjust the relations between Austria and Italy. (Reuter)
At a Cabinet Council the Ministers agreed on the measures to be adopted for the integral application of the law for the separation of the Church from the State. (Havas)

div.head: EGYPT AND CHALADEA.
THE BRONZE AND IRON AGES.
div.p: The recent discoveries in Egypt and chaldea have thrown geat light upon the relative sequence of the store, brenza, and iron ages in the East; and this evidence is particularly important, as Dr. Fr. Gnether, in the current number of the "Scientific American," proceeds to advocate the theory that "The age of bronze was a myth." The statements which the author makes in supporting his theory show an extraordinary lack of knowledge of recent archeological discoveries. After refering to the fact that in the pyramid age, about B.C. 3800, the Egyptians worked such hard materials as Prophy-bassalt and granite, he says that "there is abundant evidence that the Egyptians were acquainted with iron - not the soft, spongy iron of barbarian races, but steel." Furthermore he makes the statement that bronze was not known in Egypt in the fourth dynasty, when the pyramids were built.

The reseraches of M. de Morgan at Nagada and Professor Perrie at Abydos show that bronze was known, and fashioned into small tools for carving stone and ivory in the later Neolitic age. The recent reseraches of Professor Petrie in Sinai show that the copper mines there were worked in the time of the first dynasty. The authority of Hartland is given for the existence of deposits of iron and heaps of slag in the Wasy Magarreh. These so-called heaps of slag are now known to be the reamins of burnt offerings at the sacred cave of Hathor. There is, however, ample evidence that the bronze age and the stone age in Egypt continued side by side until at least the time of the twelfth dynasty, B.C. 2800, when the use of iron for tools or weapons never bevome general in Egypt until certainly B.C. 900. No dependence is to be placed on the supposed discovery of an iron fool in the great pyramid of Khufu, and as to the discovery of steel surgical implements and arrow heads - this could only be with Ptolemaic or Roman remains. The paintings in the tombs at Beni Hassan, B.C. 2800, show Egyptian butchers using not , as the writer says, steel knives, but flint, the process of making which is shown in other paintings, and the whetting stones are pieces of blue chert, used to smooth the edges, many of which are foundin the neigbourhood of the tombs, thrown away when useless Th eonly iron known to the Egyptians in ancient times was the meteroic iron, as its name, "the metal of heaven," shows. That the Egyptian workmen used only bronse chiseis is shown by the large numbers of them found on working sites, especially in such places as the workmen's town at Kahun. In Egypt we have, therefore proof of a stone age, into which in the later Neolitic period copper tools were introduced first, followed soon after by harder bronze implements, and it was not until the last days of the Egyptian civilisation that iron was introduced, and then only very scantily.

From Babylonia the evidenc is more clear and convincing of the bronze and copper ages. It is remarkable that, although the recent exploration in Chaldes, escpeially those of M. de Suzze at Tello and Dr. Hilprecht at Nippur, have carried the records of Babylonian civilisation back to at least B.C. 4500, there is no proof of a ston eage. This is due to the fact that the civilisation of the colonists in Shinar was developed on the cast of the Tigris, where M. de Morgan has found at Susa a series of stratified remains of the paleolithic, neolithic, and bronze age. The Sumerians brough with them the knowledge of working both silver and copper, as well as the making a bronze. In the inscription of Manishtusen in the Louvre dating from about B.C. 4500 we find a silver tariff, but also copper and bronze objects mentioned, and by names clearly distinguishing them, and there is no mention of iron. Copper, bronze, silver, and lead are mentioned as material used by Gudea in the construction of his temple, but there is no record of iron. Meteoric iron, the sign forwhich means also "thunder" "lightning," and "iron" is mentioned in the hymns, but the mention of iron first occurs in the comemrical tablets of the dynasty of Babylon anbout B.C. 2200 and it is not until later still that iron swords are mentioned. The evidence of archology from the two eldest centres of civilidation is, therefore, quite contrary to the learned doctor's conclusion "that there is no country and no race no earth on which an age of bronze has intervened between the ages of ston and iron."
(Mr. W. St. Chad. Boscawn. in the "Globs.")

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
MOSLEMS AND GREAT BRITAIN.
div.p: We trust that Lord Minto will make it clear to the deputation how entirely the British Government has the intersts of its Mohamedan subjects at heart, and how strongly determined it is to hold the balance evenly between the various section of the Indian population and not to allow an unfair dominance to any one race or creed. The dangerous and disingenuous policy adopted by the Sultan of Turkey in his realtions with Egypt has made it necessary for us to take a firm stand against a Sovereign whom Mohamedans thorughout the world regard with reverence on religious grounds. But this opposition to the Sultan on the part of the British Government does not involve, and was never meant to involve, the slightest hostility to Islam in any part of the world. It is therefore of the first importance to make it clear that not only are we not hostile as a nation to the Mohamedan creed, but that, on the contratry, we, as the geratest of Mohamedan Powers, hold it a duty to respect the rights of Islam, and to confirm those rights whenever they are legtimately exercised.

Happily, Britain can point to an absolutely clean record in regard to her treatment of Mohamedans not only in India, but in Egypt and in every other part of the world where Englishmen have come in contact with Islam. We have never interfered with the Mohamedan religion or oppressed its votaries. The Indian Mohamedans are, we belive, the throughouly loyal to our rule and appreciate our good faith. We would ask them, however, to rember that all Mohamedans do not display the high qualities shown by thmeselves, and to note that when we have been in conflict with the Sultan it has never been on religious grounds. Though in the future, as in the past, we shall not shrink from maintaining our rights to the fullest extend and in the firmest manner against Turkey, the Turkish Sovereign will never be opossed by us as Mohamedan, but, if at all, solely as a ruler who has unwisely chosen to declar himself the active enemy of the British people. The faith of Islam will never suffer from contract with our Empire. (Spectator)
The Nature Desire of Knowledge.

It is interesting and satisfactory to find that the Moeslem asked urgently for a university. Lord Minto reminded them that they have already the admirable college at Alighar. But this, after all is a small provision for a population of sixty-two millions. We have done much less in India for education, as even so partial a critic as Professor Vambery admits than the Russians in Central Asia, despire the fact that our occupatio is older by a century and the population we rule so much more intellectual than that of Turkestain. ("Tribune.")
Germany and the Entente Cordiale.

What Germany says to England and France is in plain lanage: "I consdier the friendship between you two a danger to myself in particular, and therefore to the peace of Europe in general. Your assurances to the contrary mean nothing to me who am the best, inded, the role, judge of my own judge of my own inetersts. Therefore I will not brook your close association. You must dissolve your union or else admit me to your frienship on equal terms. Unless you follow one course or the other. I shall feel obligated to try a third, and you will be morally responsible for it: I mean war. A mighty struggle between us such as took place first between Prussia and Austria and afterwards between Prussia and Austria and afterwards between Germany and France for the upper hand seemed inevitable a few months ago. And it was so conditionally not absolutely. You can yet ward off the conflict. But only in that one way. Choose!"
(Dr. Dillion in the "Contemporary Review.")
The Grand Lama's Motor.

There was a time not long ago when the GRand Lama of Thibet was "wrapped" in impenetrable mystery, but the wheels of Time move swiftly in this age of motors, and it is therefore amhsing rather than starling to read in the "Daily Telegraph" this morning that the Grand Lama is going in for an 8 h.p.car. It is to be pailged the sacred colour, yellow, and a very graphic description is given by the orespondent of how it will reach his Holiness, scaring on the way flying herds of Bamt Kyan, or tortoiseshell wild, and flocks of she drakes and car headed geese. We feel sorry for the tortoiseshell wild asses and the ducks and geese, but they cannot stop the onward sweep of the car of civilisation. They must submit to being run over or they must get out of the way. The Grand Lama will have a small lama as a chaufeur, and we hope the ffect may be to improve the roads around Lhasa.
("Westminster Gazette.")
Britain as Sea Ruler.

The prospects are that in 1909 no Continental nation will have in fighting condition one single ship fo the Dreanought typel; whereas, if the British Admiralty continue the rae of construction attained with the Dreadnough, they will then have one squadron made up of six Dreadnought, and, in addition, a sqaudron composed of eight ships of the King Edward VII. class, and two Lrod Nelsons.
("Engineering.")

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Yesterday Major Geneal the Hon.Sir. F.W. Stopford, commanding the London District, inspected the 3rd Battalion Coldsteam Guards, at Wellington Earracks, prior to its leaving for Egypt on the 29th inst. A large number of spectators was present. There were 29 officers and 700 men on parage, Colonal Granville R.F. Smith being in command, with Lieutenant Colonel J.A.G. Richardson Hay second in command. Genearl Sir Frederick Stephenson, the honoary chief of the regement, who is in his 90th year, was also present. General Stopford minutely examined the battalion, which looked exceedingly well in khaki and white helmets. According to the arrangments the Coldstreams will embark at Southemption on the S.S. Silcilia, along with a number of dragts for Alexandria, where the linear is due on the 11th OCtober. The battalion will then proceed to Cairo, where it will be quartered in Abbassieh Barracks. The 3rd Coldstreams are a fine shooting battalion. In 1903, whilst at Aldershot, they won the Field Firing Cup at the London District Rifle Meeting, the Guards Brigade Field Firing Cup, and the Regimental Shooting Cup, and in the present year they wont the "Daily Telegraph Cup," Roberts' Challenge Cup, which is open to the army, and the Cheylemore Cup, which is also open to the army.

Lieutenant Colonel P.A Kenns, V.C., D.S.O, who is so well kown in Egypt, where he served with the 21st Lancers, has just been promoted to the command of that very smart regiment. He was senior squasron officer at the time of his promotion. It may be recalled that he won the cross for valour in the wild charge of the 21st at Omdorman, by rescuing Captain Crole Wyndham from certain death, and assistaing in the attempt to recover the body of Lieutenant Grenfell. His many friends in Egypt will greatly pleased to hear of his promotion, which followed sheer professional merit.

Captain F.J.M. Postlehwaite, The King's Own Light Infantry; and Lieutenant W.F. Stirling , D.S.O., Royal Dublin fusiliers, have been seconded formally in their respective regiments for service with the Egyptian Army.

Lieutenant S.B.B. Dyer, D.S.O., 2nd Life Guards, who was recently in command of No. 4 Squadron of the Egyptian Cavalry whilst serving with the Khedive's troops, has just been prmoted captain in the Life Guards.

The battleship Hibernia, which commenced her gun and torpedo trials off Plymouth yesterday and carried them out sucessefully, is ordered to be ready by 1st Janurary next, to relive the Victorious as flaghsip of the Altantic fleet. The Hibernia's first comission will, therefore, be a higly important once. The change will take ffect at Devonport, whereit is understood the Victorious will arrive from Gilbraltar shorly before Christmas to pay off. The flag of Rear-Admiral G. Le Clerc Egerton, who recently took up his appointment as second in command of the Atlantic Fleet, will then be shifted to the Hibernia. The change will add to the homogenity of this fleet, which will then consist of seven battleships, of the King Edward VII. class, the exception being the Magnificent. The sixth ship of this group to join the Atlantic Fleet will be the Britannis, which is to replace the Majestic early next month.

Lord Brassey's tempearte, yet weighty, criticism of Admiralty naval policy has engaged considerable attention here. What Lord Brassay says in effect is that the Dreadnoughts are untried and that ther are perils to the greatest ships, as the Russo-Japanese war demonstrated, which no foresight or provision can dispel. The Dresnoughts are as liable to the blown up by mines as smaller battleships, and to be tropedoed as well, so that though the Dreadnought's fighting capacity may be all powerful yet were she and those of her class unfortunate in naval warfare the consequences would be disastrous. Morever, he points out that the fewer battleships we have diminishes the number of highly trained officers on the long list of captains who would have, under the old conditions, as opportunity of showing in the line of battle that they possess the Nelson touch. It is felt that there is a good deal in Lord Brassey's statements.

The "Daily Mail" says German esponage seems to be usually active just now. It is known that it exists in a notable degree at Portsmouth, and espceially since the Freadnought was built. The Admiralty are, for instance, perfectly well aware that at least six persons in that town alone are in the German secret service, but of course action is difficult. It is the same thing with other seasports, only in a less degree. Writing from Elenheim, New Zealand (South Island), a correspondent remarks: "Are the ruling powers of England quite blind to the aims and objects of Germany. They even have spies out here quietly working up proper maps and information of harbours, ready to land when they want to attack us. I am satisfied that England's day as Englan is past; but as part of the British Empire, under a proper Imperial Federation, it is only just beginning. We ree far more of the game here than you would think possible, and the remarks made by German Visitors, and such like, all point to the fact they think it a matter of only a few years before Australiasia will be German."

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
DISPORAL OF BULIDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
The Sudan Government will shortly dipose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Buliding Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. nRents will be payable ony from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the valye of Buildings erected by Leases will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent.

Example: If a plot is leased or a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lease will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease fro a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premium for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered. Plan of of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours:
Khartoum: * office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: * Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Said: Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T)
Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbaxi: Office of Director of Railways.
Alexandria: Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative.
London: *Office of Ct. Western, Braodway Chamber, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez: Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the conveience of intending purchases the Condition of Tender and Sale have beeen tanslated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Futher information will be obtainable after the publication of the above mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.

div.head: GOUVERNMENT DU SOUDAN.
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
AVIS
Le gouvernement du Soudan procédera bientôt à l'adjudication d'environ 400 chantiers de construction à Port-Soudan.

Les emplacements seront détenus à bail à des loyers annuels sur bail de Buliding pour quatre-vingts ans à partir du 1er janvier 1907. n Les loyers seront payables à compter de la date d'acceptation de l'offre.
Le bail sera renouvelable perpétuellement aux loyers révisés fixés par défaut à la suite d'un arbitrage par arbitrage à la fin de chaque période d'années.
En fixant les loyers révisés, la valeur des bâtiments construits par les baux ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

Exemple: Si une parcelle est louée ou une durée de 80 ans à compter du 1er janvier 1907, à l'expiration de ce délai, le bail aura le droit (sous réserve du respect de son contrat etc.) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 ans. années à un loyer révisé, et ainsi de suite à perpétuité. Le loyer révisé sera calculé sur la valeur que le site supporterait s'il s'agissait de terrains à bâtir vacants.
Les offres de Prime sont sollicitées pour l'Achat des sites à bail mentionnés ci-dessus.
Toutes les offres doivent être faites par Tender, sur les formulaires délivrés par le Gouvernement soudanais, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum au plus tard le 1er janvier 1907.

Particularités des sites proposés. Le plan de la ville, les conditions de soumission et de vente, le mode de soumission, le modèle de bail, etc., seront ouverts à compter du 1er octobre 1906 aux endroits suivants pendant les heures d'ouverture habituelles:
Khartoum: * bureau du directeur de l'agriculture et des terres (T) et bureau du gouverneur de la province de Khartoum.
Le Caire: * Agent du bureau du Soudan (T).
Port-Saïd: Bureau de l'inspecteur (Bureau du gouvernement) (T)
Suakin: Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de la Mer Rouge.
El Damer: Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province Berbère.
Atbaxi: Bureau du directeur des chemins de fer.
Alexandrie: Bureau de M. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Saïd: Bureau de Dixon Bey, représentant du bureau de la guerre.
Londres: * Bureau du Ct. Western, Chambre Braodway, Westminster, et la Cour du Soudan, Imperial Institute.
Suez: Bureau du capitaine Falconer, représentant du War Office.

Pour la commodité des achats envisagés, les conditions de l'offre et de la vente ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies des traductions dans l'une ou l'autre langue seront disponibles après le 1er octobre 1906 moyennant le versement de 5 p. par copie dans les Offices de la liste ci-dessus, qui se distinguent par une lettre T.
